abstract.text: The parameters of the seasonal modulations (variations) in the intensity of muons and cosmogenic neutrons generated by them at a mean muon energy of 280 GeV have been determined in the LVD (Large Volume Detector) experiment.
The modulations of muons and neutrons are caused by a temperature effect, the seasonal temperature and density variations of the upper atmospheric layers.

The analysis performed here leads to the conclusion that the variations in the mean energy of the muon flux are the main source of underground cosmogenic neutron variations, because the energy of muons is more sensitive to the temperature effect than their intensity.

The parameters of the seasonal modulations in the mean energy of muons and the flux of cosmogenic neutrons at the LVD depth have been determined from the data obtained over seven years of LVD operation.

body_text.text: Introduction

At present, the correlation between the annual modulations in the counting rate of events observed in dark matter particle search experiments [1], [2], [3], [4] and the seasonal variations in the underground muon flux is being actively discussed.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The muon intensity variations at great depths are considered as a possible source of the seasonal modulations of events in low-background detectors.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: It is assumed that the modulations can be produced by cosmogenic neutrons whose flux is linearly related to the varying muon flux.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The cause of the seasonal muon variations at sea level and underground is well known [5], [6], [7].
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: This is a temperature effect that leads to a change in the density of the terrestrial atmosphere and its height as a result of its heating in summer and cooling in winter.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: On the one hand, a decrease in the density of the upper atmospheric layers (stratosphere) through expansion when heated leads to an increase in the probability of the π → µ decays of first generation charged pions from extensive air showers (EASs) and to a corresponding decrease in the number of pions (and the number of their decays π → µ) in the last generations.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: On the other hand, the atmosphere expansion increases the probability of the µ → e decays of low energy muons on their way to the Earth.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The first fact, an increase in the probability of the decays π → µ, gives a positive temperature effect observed in the high energy muon flux.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The last two facts associated with low energy muons lead to a negative temperature effect, a reduction in the muon intensity at sea level, where the mean muon energy is ∼ 4 GeV.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The observed muon variations are determined by the combined action of the negative and positive effects.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The negative component dominates approximately down to 20 meters water equivalent (m w.e.).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Its contribution is decreased with a depth increasing and becomes negligible starting from approximately 200 m w.e. (E µ = 35 GeV).
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Muons at energies above 1 TeV produced at pA-interaction energies above 100 TeV can reach depths greater than 2 km w.e. The positive temperature effect is clearly observed at large underground facilities [8], [9], [10].
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: In the LVD [11] experiment the parameters of seasonal variations both muon intensity and number of neutrons produced by muons for a fixed time interval (60 days) in LVD structure were determined.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The puzzle of the data obtained is inequality of amplitudes of the neutron number modulation and modulation of muon intensity: the first is about 10 times greater than the second one.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: This problem can be solved by assuming seasonal variations of the muon flux mean energy which determines the neutron production.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The positive temperature effect increases the probability of the decays of first pion generations in EAS.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: This must lead not only to a rise in the intensity of muons at great depths but also to an increase in their mean energy.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Below, we will estimate the seasonal variations in the mean muon energy and the variations in the number of neutrons produced by muons using the LVD data [9], [11].

body_text.text: Conclusions
The variations δE µ in the mean energy of the muon flux are the main source of seasonal variations in the underground cosmogenic neutron flux.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: The relative amplitude of the neutron variations related to δE µ exceeds the relative modulation amplitude δI µ by an order of magnitude.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: This is explained by a stronger dependence of the energy on the temperature effect than that for I µ .
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: Taking into account the dependence of the temperature coefficient α T on depth (the decrease of α T with decreasing depth), which relates the seasonal muon intensity variations ∆I µ /I µ to the atmospheric temperature variations ∆T /T [4], [6], [8], one should expect a corresponding depth dependence of the coefficient k E n and, as a consequence, E max µ .
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: Apart from the seasonal modulations, the temperature of the upper atmospheric layers undergoes irregular variations over a year.
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: As a result, the number of neutrons produced by muons underground deviates considerably from the harmonic function (2) with a breakdown of the constancy of the modulation amplitude δN and the fluctuation phase t n 0 .
body_text.section: Conclusions

body_text.text: This should be taken into account when analyzing the background in low-background underground experiments.
